Experiment Method.Assay Method: Planar lipid bilayers and Langmuir monolayer techniques

Material used.Material Source: In vitro phosphatidylcholine bilayers with added gangliosides (GM3 or GM1)
Material used.Description: The study utilized synthetic phosphatidylcholine bilayers reconstituted with purified α-Synuclein mutants and varying concentrations of gangliosides.

Readout description.Result Description: The E46K mutant exhibited significantly reduced conductance compared to wild-type α-Synuclein in the presence of GM3, while GM1 showed no such effect.

Biological replicates.Description: No information provided on biological replicates.

Technical replicates.Description: No information provided on technical replicates.

Basic positive control.Description: No basic positive control described in the study.

Basic negative control.Description: No basic negative control described in the study.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Normal conductance levels were inferred based on wild-type α-Synuclein behavior.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Abnormal conductance levels were defined by significantly reduced ion flux compared to wild-type under similar conditions.

Approved assay.Description: Planar lipid bilayer techniques are commonly used to study membrane protein function and ion channel activity, making this approach suitable for studying α-Synuclein in the context of Parkinson's disease.
